results.title: All the days of my life
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.
results.description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.

results.title: War, tears and memories
results.creator_credit: Jean Parry and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jean’s greatest memory was the Battle of Alemein. She remembers the noise and the booming of the guns and the flood of patients needing attention. Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.
results.description: Jean’s greatest memory was the Battle of Alemein. She remembers the noise and the booming of the guns and the flood of patients needing attention. Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.

results.title: Battle for Australia
results.creator_credit: Jean King and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war
results.description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war

results.title: When quiet came
results.creator_credit: Bill Flowers and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.
results.description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.

results.title: Head of Instagram scrambles after backlash
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @mosseri's Instagram post
results.brief_description: Instagram has been trialling some new features for video content- and they have not been well received. Following criticism from some high profile celebrities, ranging from Kylie Jenner to Roxane Gay, Head of Instagram Adam Mosseri posted a defense of the platform’s perceived pivot to video, euphemistically acknowledging the changes as “not yet good.” Mosseri seems worried, and he’s right to be: Jenner, who has 361 million Instagram followers, is not averse to exerting her influence. In 2018 her criticism of a Snapchat update caused the company to lose US$1.3billion in market value, and they quickly withdrew several changes.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Instagram has been trialing some new features for video content - and they have not been well received. Following criticism from some high profile celebrities, ranging from Kylie Jenner to Roxane Gay, Head of Instagram Adam Mosseri posted a defense of the platform’s perceived pivot to video, euphemistically acknowledging the changes as “not yet good”. Mosseri seems worried, and he’s right to be: Jenner, who has 361 million Instagram followers, is not averse to exerting her influence. In 2018 her criticism of a Snapchat update caused the company to lose US$1.3billion in market value, and they quickly withdrew several changes.
description_for_label: Instagram has been trialing some new features for video content - and they have not been well received. Following criticism from some high profile celebrities, ranging from Kylie Jenner to Roxane Gay, Head of Instagram Adam Mosseri posted a defense of the platform’s perceived pivot to video, euphemistically acknowledging the changes as “not yet good”. Mosseri seems worried, and he’s right to be: Jenner, who has 361 million Instagram followers, is not averse to exerting her influence. In 2018 her criticism of a Snapchat update caused the company to lose US$1.3billion in market value.

results.title: “We will adopt your baby”
results.brief_description: This week the US Supreme Court’s overturned the landmark ruling Roe v. Wade. Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing - and memes. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase with its genesis in pro-life counter-protest signs. It has quickly become a meme deriding the offensive and unreasonable response of Christian conservatives who promote adoption as a “solution” to the dismantling of life-saving reproductive rights. Tiktok users like @tacobelldollamenu use cynical humour to reveal the lie of this rhetoric: if adoption is the solution, why does the US have a crisis in the foster system? Where are all these pro-lifers’ happily adopted kids?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

This week the US Supreme Court overturned the landmark Roe v Wade ruling. Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing – and memes – both in support and opposition to the controversial ruling. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase that started as a slogan on pro-life counter-protest signs. It’s quickly become a meme deriding the response of some conservatives who propose adoption as an alternative to abortion.

TikTok users like @tacobelldollamenu use cynical humour to expose what they see as the failing of this rhetoric, while others used the meme’s visibility to point out that many children in America’s foster system are in need.
description_for_label: This week the US Supreme Court overturned the landmark Roe v Wade ruling. Social media is awash with protests, political speeches, resource sharing – and memes – both in support and opposition to the controversial ruling. ‘We will adopt your baby’ is a phrase that started as a slogan on pro-life counter-protest signs. It’s quickly become a meme deriding the response of some conservatives who propose adoption as an alternative to abortion. TikTok users like @tacobelldollamenu use cynical humour to expose what they see as the failing of this rhetoric.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Joe Biden takes a tumble
results.brief_description: US President Joe Biden fell off his bike after stopping to greet a group of reporters and members of the public while out for a ride in Delaware. Footage of the incident shared online sparked countless memes that spoofed the presidential pratfall. By splicing together videos, this Twitter user joked that it was former President Trump’s golf shot that caused the tumble.
results.description: Footage of US President Joe Biden falling from his bike has sparked countless memes spoofing the presidential pratfall. This one splices the original with Donald Trump golfing to suggest the former president is responsible for the fall. It’s a right-wing meme, but there have also been left-wing memes created to criticise Biden’s inability to achieve his more progressive policies. Both sides of politics use memes, but the alt-right, in particular, have weaponised the format’s humour and irony to spread hate.
description_for_label: Footage of US President Joe Biden falling from his bike has sparked countless memes spoofing the presidential pratfall. This one splices the original with Donald Trump golfing to suggest the former president is responsible for the fall. It’s a right-wing meme, but there have also been left-wing memes created to criticise Biden’s inability to achieve his more progressive policies. Both sides of politics use memes, but the alt-right, in particular, have weaponised the format’s humour and irony to spread hate.

results.title: Max floating to songs
results.brief_description: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past & present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

Social media users across the internet have also used special effects programs to show themselves levitating, or running out of the Upside Down from Vecna, often to their favourite songs, which they’ve edited into the visuals. This has allowed the scene to spawn numerous meme templates.

The personal element of the narrative - that your favourite song can save you from evil - and the nostalgia of the series lends itself to users contributing their own songs (and associated emotions) to the visuals, creating a personal but collective, shareable experience.

Another prominent meme created from Stranger Things 4 relies on sound. Before claiming his victims, Vecna makes them hallucinate a ticking grandfather clock (among other things) and its ominous chime (used to great effect in horror movies forever) has become an eerie indicator that he’s coming for you. Naturally, TikTokers have appropriated the sound for comedic effect. Know Your Meme traces the first use of it to user @marcusbtv, who hears it in a skit about gaming, removes one headphone and says “Nope….. not getting me”, before going back to playing.

It’s now been repurposed and reused across the internet, with users often engaging with an invisible clock (they’re hallucinating) or even Big Ben.
description_for_label: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Random guy welcomes American protagonist
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @paharikawa's TikTok post
results.brief_description: TikTokker, Aslan Pahari, satirical take on the depiction of non-white characters in mainstream films
results.description: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Aslan Pahari – known for his satirical anthropological content – skewers the noble and wise Middle Eastern guide who typically leads American ‘heroes’ through supposedly ‘exotic’ lands. By combining tired tropes of Arabic culture – sand dunes, ‘wobbly air’, ‘traditional’ singing – he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic and Islamic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. By including videos from other users calling out stereotypes, Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture.
description_for_label: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Here, Aslan Pahari skewers the noble and wise guide in supposedly ‘exotic’ locales. By combining tired cinema tropes of Arab culture, he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture by including videos from other users lampooning stereotypes.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.brief_description: Trans actress and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.
results.title_for_label: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.description:

Trans actor and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.

Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter.
